Topic.Title: What do think of Merrill Edge self directed?

Message.Msg: I've been with Merrill Wealth Management mlpa for over 12 years. About 10 years i decided to do my own trades. I don't pay for the trades but they hit me with quarterly fee that is a fixed % of my account which adds up to many thousands a year. I am thinking of switching to Merrill Edge and if they don't work, Fidelity.

Message.Title: Global Unemployment to Surge Past 2009 Record World Unemployment to Hit Record High in 2013
Message.Msg: World unemployment could top record levels this year and continue rising until 2017, the International Labour Organization (ILO) said on Tuesday in its annual employment report. 2009 currently stands as the worst recorded year for world unemployment, with 198 million people across the globe without work. In its 2013 Global Employment Trends report, the ILO forecasts unemployment numbers will rise by 5.1 million in 2013 to reach 202 million, topping 2009's record. Global Unemployment to Surge Past 2009 Record World Unemployment to Hit Record High in 2013

Message.Title: President Martin Schulz views the European Union as headed for a depression
Message.Msg: European Parliament President Martin Schulz views the European Union as headed for a depression Feb 4, 2013 Schulz says EU on path to depression: report European Parliament President Martin Schulz views the European Union as headed for a depression, according to an interview with Saturday's edition of the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung. "[The E.U.] is on a path to a depression, apathy, a mood of not caring. That's dangerous, as that mood superimposes the great successes of the E.U., for which it recently won the Nobel Peace Prize," Mr. Schulz is quoted as saying.

Message.Title: check out ltbr
Message.Msg: Lightbridge Corp. (LTBR) Lightbridge Corporation is a nuclear fuel technology company powering up the nuclear sector's advancement. The Company has two divisions: a nuclear fuel technology group and a business consulting group. Lightbridge serves as one of the leading nuclear power consulting and strategic advisory services to both commercial and governmental entities worldwide. Lightbridge's subsidiaries include Thorium Power, Inc., and Lightbridge International Holding, LLC. With its three fuel product lines, Lightbridge is poised to capture market share as it has developed the next generation of nuclear fuel. In a nutshell, the advanced technology allows existing reactors to produce more electricity for improved economics and longer fuel cycles. The Company has earned patents from the U.S. government and other international entities, including Russia and South Korea. Investors looking for a company with no long-term debt will note that Lightbridge has never had to bear that burden. With a market cap of $20.67 million, and an EPS of -0.42 analysts anticipate licensing revenues to generate, conservatively, $200 million. If the conservative projection bears out, ROI will be in the neighborhood of ~300%. Further, Lightbridge is the current lowest valued company in the nuclear market, evidenced by comparison to its competitors such as Vringo (VRNG). To date, there are 66 nuclear power plants under construction, and with clients that include Duke Energy (DUK), Dominion (D), Exelon (EXC) and Southern Company (SO), we fully anticipate Lightbridge will power alpha this year.

Message.Title: Fortress unit to refinance 1 bln euro loan, scraps asset sale
Message.Msg: FRANKFURT | Mon Feb 4, 2013 1:22pm EST Feb 4 (Reuters) - German real estate group Gagfah , controlled by U.S. investor Fortress, is to refinance a 1 billion euro ($1.4 billion) loan of its Woba unit, leading it to scrap the sale of the division. "Upon the completion of this transaction, Gagfah will have made a significant step towards resolving its 2013 debt maturities," the company said on Monday. Bank of America will lend Gagfah the money, a person close to the German real estate company said.

Topic.Title: How would a Merrill Lynch spinoff affect current shareholders?

Message.Msg: I wouldn't invest a lot of time in that line of thought. Investment banking is a core requirement for money center banking for corporate & comm'l accounts, and WIM is core to higher end clients (pvt bk and mass affluent) who have deeper relationships and drive fee revenue. If BAC were to spin off ML, it would have to re-create it, sans expertise. Not going to happen.

Topic.Title: BAC is HEADED to 3.59 by AUGUST 2013!!!! JUST CHECK MY OTHER LONG-TERM PREDICTIONS

Message.Msg: Laughable that you pulled a number out of thin air for your support level. If the stock is going to tank 75%, why should it stop at $3.59? Better yet, can you give us a more specific date in August when this will all occur? We'd all like to sell our stocks the day before and convert to gold, if you don't mind. In this political and regulatory environment, and with the capital levels that would have to be headed for depletion to accomplish what you say, the stock would simply go to zero on the friday that the regulators would take over. Your scenario is simply not going to happen without a major catalyst. And if that catalyst appears, your money won't be worth anything anymore anyway. A broken clock is right twice a day.

Topic.Title: BAC is HEADED to 3.59 by AUGUST 2013!!!! JUST CHECK MY OTHER LONG-TERM PREDICTIONS

Message.Msg: I'm not saying it can't happen. If this country cannot push itself away from the table of government-sponsored solutions to government-created problems, then I think TX's prediction of a support level is optimistic, and that's what I was basically saying. But thinking along the lines of what it would take for such an event to occur now, after the credit policy belt has been tightened to the point that the food has backed up toward the esophagus... It just doesn't seem plausible, nor does it seem to reflect the realities of the current economic environment. No, we aren't creating jobs (the notion we are is fabulously misrepresented as the workforce contracts month over month). No, we aren't showing signs of economic growth, not in the classical sense. But in the new norm of Jimmy Carter 2 where malaise reigns supreme, we seem to be finding our way, accepting the new circumstances, the new normal (so to speak) of government populist blundering on a herculean scale. And in that light, I'd expect nothing more than a flat trajectory until the banking world can toss aside the newfound regulations -- imposed by the chief architects of the last crisis -- and start delivering "free" products to consumers that generate huge revenues from merchants. And now my rose colored glasses need to be cleaned.

Topic.Title: How would a Merrill Lynch spinoff affect current shareholders?

Message.Msg: Banks don't flex their balance sheets to earn interest income from loans at the lowest possible rates of return. They do it to get the investment banking business in the first place. That's the concept, anyway. The picture you describe is exactly what the IB houses wanted in the 90's. The banks didn't go for it, instead electing to cut off lending for corporates that had single-sourced their lucrative IB fee business elsewhere. The IBs didn't have the balance sheet of real banks, so they couldn't play ball by lending. That pictorial of a bank playing with an IB firm is not synergistic, it's predatory on the part of the IB for as long as the bank is stupid enough to send all of the good revenue to the IB.

Topic.Title: How would a Merrill Lynch spinoff affect current shareholders?
